Capitals:  
[Anshan](Anshan.html) up to the proto-elamite state 4th to 3rd millennium and [Susa](Susa.html) afterwards.

# El'Limes
ğ’Œ‹ğ’€¸ğ’‹°ğ’†¸ğ’ˆ¨ğ’„‘ eli-mi-is limis boundary

ğ’„¬ hal country    ğ’„©ğ’€   hal; ha-al  hill ğ’„¬ < ğ’†³ kur "elevated" [EL](EL.html) â‡§  

ğœ¾ğœ…ğœ‚ğœ”ğœ…ğœ§ ×” TamÊ¿ti  
ğœ‘ ğœ‘ ğœ‘Ÿ ğœ‘  Temi Demi Semi  
ğ’‹ Å EÅ 2 Susa â‡” Semi  
ğ’‚ Å EÅ 4  Susa  
ğ’‚ EREN Iran Elam  

The rivalry between powers of Irak ( Eridu, Uruk, Sumer Akkad Babylon ) and Iran ( Ray Susa Anshan Jiroft )  
swang back and forth like a pendulum:  
At the beginning and end of the [Ubaid](Ubaid.html) period, Iran was slightly higher developed than the alluvium, but in the [Uruk](Uruk.html) period Susa II and Syrian Anatolian enclaves of Uruk reveal a clear dominance of Mesopotamian powers.  
In the Jamdat Nasr period the Uruk state disintegrated into balkanized city states

Unfortunately neither Elamaite nor Harappan/Indus script currently have unicode blocks.  
Many Elamite signs are familiar from other systems:  
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Puzur-Shushinak.jpg/240px-Puzur-Shushinak.jpg)  
[ğ’…¤](ğ’…¤.html)[ğ’Š­](ğ’Š­.html)[ğ’€­](ğ’€­.html)[ğ’ˆ¹](ğ’ˆ¹.html) [ğ’‚](ğ’‚.html) puzurğ’€­Å¡uÅ¡inak = ğ’Œ‹ğ’Œ‹ğ’€­ğ’ˆ¹ğ’‚

k â‹ à¤• â‹ ğŒŠK in one form:  
![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/516118/122801376-4e0f9880-d2c4-11eb-9003-0ac248eba5a9.png)  

Only the letter shi seems like a mismatch wa? â‹ğ€· â‹ğ˜®? â‹ğ“‡¯? pta?  

While the 'n' in Inshushinak does contain an [ğ“ˆ–](ğ“ˆ–.html) (n), we suspect a more complicated reading, similar to [EN](EN.html) [ğ’‚—](ğ’‚—.html)  
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Inshushinak_%28Linear_Elamite%29.jpg/140px-Inshushinak_%28Linear_Elamite%29.jpg)  

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Ha-ta-m-ti.jpg/180px-Ha-ta-m-ti.jpg)  
The letters ta and ti in Ha-ta-m-ti seem about right given their similarity to [Î¸](Î¸.html), [ğ“Š•](ğ“Š•.html) and [dual](dual.html)ity  
One might be closer to t[c](c.html) though.  

The letter ha corresponds graphically, phonetically to [ğ’„¬](ğ’„¬.html), even in its usage (and semantically?) in ğ’¹[ğ’„¬](ğ’„¬.html)[ğ’†·](ğ’†·.html)[ğ’¶](ğ’¶.html)[ğ’‹¾](ğ’‹¾.html) ğ’¹-Hal-La-tam-ti â€¢haltamti â‹ Hatamti  
Given the universal reading of [kur](kur.html)-signs similar to [ğ’† ](ğ’† .html) ki, we suggest that Ha<Ka  

[New evidence](https://www.academia.edu/36567114/Linear_Elamite_writing) shows that Elamite was continuously in use from proto-elamite 3200 BC to Linear Elamite 1850 BC, until it was fully replaced with the cuneiform representation of elamite and finally disappeared around 300BC. It developed as a sister system with the Sumerian language from a common ancestry of counting tablets with select logograms.  

The Elamite language is still not fully deciphered, but [some words](https://github.com/pannous/hieros/blob/master/dicts/swadesh/elamite.tsv) indicate the presence of [wanderword](wanderword.html)s:

Given that Egypt had [very strong ties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Mesopotamia_relations) [with Elam](home) in the 4th millennium, it is unsurprising, that many of the above words are similar in both languages.

# Ishtar Esther Eastern
Ishtar may be associated with the Eastern Venus. â‡” Queen Vashti  
The Book of Esther "the Megillah" "the Scroll" takes place in Elam 5th BCE  
Mordecai â‰ˆ  Marduk  
The story of a Jewish woman in Persia, born as Hadassah but known as Esther, who becomes queen of Persia and thwarts a genocide of her people. Eating HamanTashen (transl. "Haman's pockets / ears")  
on the 14th day of the Hebrew month of Adar
